content:
[gsavli]
ok, ti, ki si bolj pameten, boš znal pojasnit, zakaj manjka zgornja
polovica reaktorske zgradbe? če se je pa samo sesul hladilni
sistem? a so jo sami razstrelili, da se reaktorska zgradba
"zrači"?
Hydrogen gas is produced when a plant operates. This represents an
explosion risk when it mixes with air. Plants are equipped with
hydrogen ignitors (basically spark plugs) that try to ignite small
amounts of hydrogen so that large amounts cannot accumulate.
During the venting, hydrogen was allowed to mix with air. The
ignitors failed through a combination of: a) being overwhelmed by
the rapid release b) the high humidity/condensation that was
undoubtedly present prevented proper sparking.
A large hydrogen explosion occurred. People who have seen the
high-school demonstration of hydrogen burning will note the amazing
similarity between that and what we are seeing on video
feeds.
This appears to have blown the siding off the reactor
building.
This is VERY VERY different from the kind of explosion that
happened at Chernobyl. Had there been a massive breach of the core,
there would have been evidence in the video feeds. Xrays, Cerenkov
radiation and other fancy light shows would likely have been
visible on the video.
